1125940641836331008.text:
While it is unclear yet if Binance will do it, this is an interesting instance in which PoS system would be more secure that PoW.

By even just revealing the keys for say 25% of those 7000 $BTC @cz_binance could in theory rewrite the history.

#SAFUhttps://twitter.com/JeremyRubin/status/1125919526485254144 …

1125807411195830273.text: 12/12 And thus @nearprotocol, as a platform for user-facing applications, will most certainly have on-chain governance from day 1. While I would argue that Ethereum 1.x shall never have it.

1125807409882996736.text: 11/n In the meantime, any argument on on-chain governance must always be in the context of the use-case. User-facing DeFi applications will never succeed without well-specified governance, since people need to be certain they don't lose money for bugs they are not responsible for

1125807408557711365.text:
10/n Respecting Ether minted on 2.0 on 1.x chain, however, is crucial for Ethereum 2.0 to succeed.

That will be an interesting action to observe. Way more eventful than ProgPoW.

1125807407425150976.text: 9/n Similarly, I personally don't believe that the community will allow Ether minted on Ethereum 2.0 chain to be respected by Ethereum 1.0 chain, since it will effectively require the Eth1.0 chain respect the security of Eth2.0.

1125807405990703104.text: 8/n I also believe that Ethereum 1.x is a great candidate for the former, but Ethereum 2.0 is not. Thus, I don't believe that any attempt of Ethereum Foundation to deprecate Eth1.0 in favour of Eth2.0 will work in the long term.

1125807404761747456.text: 7/n My personal belief is that in the bright world of the future there will be one slow extremely secure (most likely PoW) chain with code-is-law governance, and another one (or may be a multitude of) PoS chain that is extremely fast, and has an on-chain governance process.

1125807403646111744.text: 6/n Importantly, for many other use cases there must be an extremely secure chain that has *no* governance and on which the code is law. Interestingly, such chain doesn't need to be either fast or cheap.

1125807402622701568.text: 5/n Where exactly the line on the spectrum from a clear bug in the contract and a clear negligence on my end lies is not as important for as long as the process of deciding it is clearly specified somewhere.

1125807401381163008.text: 4/n I as a use would prefer to use a chain with some level of well-specified governance (whether onchain or offchain) so that if such a bug is detected, I am certain that my money will be recovered.

1125807400202596353.text: 3/n Static analysis only catches what is known, and formal verification only verifies what you ask it to verify. Both increase chances of correctness, but don't guarantee it.

1125807398566879232.text: 2/n Even if we rule out obscure cases like MakerDAO, in which the code is intentionally obfuscated, there are probably dozens slight issues like parity multisig or DAO hack in the well-written contracts deployed today.

1125807396763254784.text:
1/n So on-chain governance.

Consider myself, as a target audience for DeFi. I'd never invest any amount of money that is subjectively "large" (for me) into any smart contract, because any bug in that smart contract will mean my money are gone.

1113190436464549889.text:
The latter is particularly important, since our hypothesis is that reducing the barrier for developers to start building for blockchains is crucial to grow the adoption.

Zilliqa, as the first comer, will prove or disprove many things about sharding. Let's see how it all unrolls.

1113190435399147520.text: @nearprotocol is different from Zilliqa on those two dimensions: we do build state sharding, which makes the state explosion problem significantly less severe; and we support any language that compiles to WASM for smart contracts (promoting TypeScript as the primary one).

1113190434564501504.text: While their smart contracts are not live yet, once they are, it will also be interesting to see how much of a barrier it is for developers to learn Scilla. Scilla has many benefits as a smart contract language, but does require higher commitment from developers to start building.

1113190433629171712.text: It is also exciting to see how network sharding performs without state sharding. There was a very active argument in the Zilliqa's telegram, where some people (myself included) were arguing that state size is proportional to the TPS, and thus will explode quickly.

1113190432375156736.text: It is exciting because in terms of TPS on simple transactions (both intra-shard and cross-shard payments, and intra-shard smart contracts) Zilliqa shall scale very well; Way beyond what is needed today.

1069796632990953472.text:
4. Malicious actor mines 5 more blocks in shard 1 on top of the invalid block and finalizes all of them
5. Malicious actor then performs a cross-shard transaction to move those tokens out of the corrupted chain to another shard.

What prevents this scenario from happening?

1069796632118448129.text:
To be more specific, the scenario:
1. 50 shards, each has ~1% mining power.
2. Malicious actor with 1% mining power sends all the resources to shard 1.
3. Malicious actor mines an invalid block in shard 1 that mints 1B tokens out of thin air and finalizes it on the root chain

1061512046628335616.text: 4.1/ Overall, the only way to see how it all works is to try in practice, so excited to see how @tezos evolves, and looking forward to @polkadotnetwork and @dfinity launch to see on-chain governance in the wild.

1061512046125056000.text: 3.3/ Which is yet another argument against an ability to temper with the state of all smart contracts via on-chain governance.

1061512045512650753.text:
3.2/ In a hypothetical liquid democracy corrupting few @VitalikButerin's of the World would be sufficient to pass any change.
Even without liquid democracy such popular figures would be able to sway voters towards a particular decision via social media.

1061512044631883778.text: 3.1/ Liquid democracy (and @dfinity nervous system) is inherently vulnerable to few people being in control of major decisions. Those people trying to stay anonymous is unlikely to help, for most of them it is obvious that they have a high weight.

1061512043763707904.text:
2.1/ Storing the runtime on-chain (@polkadotnetwork-style) is a major vulnerability. Any minor bug in block processing opens up opportunities for custom code execution exploits.
#bitcoin's approach with voting on-chain, but distributing code off-chain appears to be safer choice.

1061512042937409539.text: 1.4/ Moreover, the sheer presence of the "do not temper" flag is sufficient reason to advocate against the hard fork shall any bug be exploited, since contract users were aware of the flag and assumed the risk.

1061512042085965824.text:
1.3/ @dominic_w argues that it doesn't solve the problem since the client code can be changed through on-chain governance to have a hardcoded state transition anyway (like, again, TheDAO).
I disagree with @dominic_w, the increased complexity will make it significantly more rare.

1061512040986996736.text:
1.2/
The reasonable solution is to have a flag in smart contracts indicating whether their state can be tampered with via on-chain governance.
This is not my idea, @timothanke suggested it for DFinity couple years back (https://medium.com/dfinity/the-dfinity-blockchain-nervous-system-a5dd1783288e …, search for "Omnipotence")

1061512040374689792.text:
1.1/ Few thoughts on on-chain governance:
Ability to update state via on-chain governance bypassing the state-transition function is super dangerous and invalidates the core idea behind smart contracts.
Yet it is necessary since things like TheDAO will be happening.

1058486671602257920.text: 4/ Either way, a corruptible minority setting is completely unreasonable in my opinion.

1058486669849042944.text: 3/ But if we assume that less than 50% of validators are corruptible to begin with, why not preselect the validators in advance? I always thought that the entire point of not revealing oneself before doing useful work is exactly to avoid corruption.

1058486667886190593.text:
2/ To that @silviomicali responded that if I can corrupt >50% of validators in such a way, such validators were corruptible, and corruptible is dishonest, while we operate under a honest majority assumption.

I.e. @Algorand assumes a corruptible minority setting.

1058486663427604482.text:
1/ Today @silviomicali said that @Algorand is secure under an assumption that an adversary can corrupt any participant.

I raised a concern that an adversary can in principle corrupt validators before they reveal themselves (e.g. as described in this post https://medium.com/nearprotocol/how-unrealistic-is-bribing-frequently-rotated-validators-d859adb464c8 …)pic.twitter.com/JqwKe87DXa

1055510947458994176.text: But it seems like most of the sharded blockchain protocols built today are built with an assumption that the problem doesn't exist.

1055510738473693184.text:
Other solutions that I don't think work:
 - using zk-sharks: is too slow
 - some sort of merge mining (e.g. @kadena_io): is bypassed by corrupting few shards instead of one, see https://twitter.com/AlexSkidanov/status/1055317598101880837 …

Some game theoretic solution with challenges might work.

1055509964771315717.text:
Problem: on a blockchain with 1K shards one shard gets completely corrupted and creates a block that prints 1B tokens out of thin air.

A common solution is to assume that rotating validators frequently makes it almost impossible. I argue that it doesn't:https://medium.com/nearprotocol/how-unrealistic-is-bribing-frequently-rotated-validators-d859adb464c8 …
